question: Shit. Excuse me? I was misquoted. I was merely speculating on the evolutionary scenario of a Lost World. I never said I was in any such place. Ian Malcolm Not really.
answer: Ian! Don't linger in the doorway like an ingenue, come in, come in!

question: Resentful.
answer: When you have a lot of time to think, it's funny who you remember. It's the people who challenged you. It is the quality of our opponents that gives our accomplishments meaning. I never told you how sorry I was about what happened after we returned.

question: I didn't know you -- weren't well.
answer: It's the lawyers. The lawyers are finally killing me.

question: They do have motives. Why did you want to see me? Your message said it was urgent.
answer: You were right -- and I was wrong. There! Did you ever think you'd hear me say that? Spectacularly wrong. Instead of observing those animals, I tried to control them. I squandered an opportunity and we still know next to nothing about their lives. Not their lives as man would have them, behind electric fences, but in the wild. Behavior in their natural habitat, the impossible dream of any paleontologist. I could have had it, but I let it slip away. Thank God for Site B.

question: What?
answer: Well? Didn't it all seem a trifle compact to you?

question: What are you talking about?
answer: The hatchery, in particular? You know my initial yields had to be low, far less than one percent, that's a thousand embryos for every single live birth. Genetic engineering on that scale implies a giant operation, not the spotless little laboratory I showed you.

question: I don't believe you.
answer: Isla Nublar was just a showroom, Ian, something for the tourists, Site B was the factory floor. We built it first, on Isla Sorna, eight-some miles from Nublar.

question: No, no, no, no, no, no . . .
answer: After the accident at the park, a hurricane wiped out our facility on Site B. We had to evacuate and leave the animals to fend for themselves. And they did. For four years I've fought to keep them safe from human meddling, now I want you to go there and document them.

question: Are you out of your mind? I still have nightmares, my reputation's a joke, my leg is shot -- you think I need more of that?
answer: It would be the most extraordinary living fossil record the world has ever seen.

question: So what?
answer: I've been putting this together for over a year.

question: John . . .
answer: You'll need an animal behaviorist, someone with unimpeachable credentials. I believe you already know Sarah Harding. She's got theories about parenting and nurturing among hunter/scavengers I bet she'd be dying to prove on a scale like this. If you convince her to go, it'll be a major coup. When she publishes, the scientific community must take it seriously. Your documentation, you should use forensic photographic methods, Hasselbladt still cameras, high definition video. When the trick photography analysts take your evidence apart, make it impossible for them to say there was enhancement or computer graphic imaging. Oh, this is very important -- avoid the island interior at all costs. Stick to the outer rim. Everything you need to know can be found there. Vindication lies on the outer rim.

question: I'm not going, John.
answer: Ian, you are my last chance to give something of real value to the world. I can't walk so far and leave no footprints; die and leave nothing with my name on it. I will not be known only for my failures. And you will not allow yourself to go down in history as a lunatic. You're too smart. You'e too proud. Dr. Malcolm. Please. This is a chance at redemption. For both of us. There's no time to equivocate, we must seize it now, before --

question: Hello, Uncle John. Dr. Malcolm.
answer: Find someone else.

question: So, you two were just, uh, telling old campfire stories, were you?
answer: Do me a favor. Don't pretend for a second that you and I don't know the truth. You can convince Time magazine and the Skeptical Inquirer of whatever you want, but I was there.

question: You signed a non-disclosure agreement before you went to the island that expressly forbade you from discussing anything you saw. You violated that agreement.
answer: You cost me my livelihood. That on which I relied to support my children.

question: If your university felt you were causing it embarrassment by selling wild stories to Hard Copy, I hardly see how I am to--
answer: I didn't tell anything, I told the truth.

question: You version of it.
answer: There are no versions of the truth! This isn't a corporate maneuver, it's my life.

question: We made a generous compensatory offer for your injuries.
answer: It was a payoff and an insult. InGen never--

question: InGen is my livelihood, Dr. Malcolm, and I will jealously defend its interests. People will know what I want them to know when I want them to know it.
answer: Do you have a satellite phone?

question: Ajay?
answer: How did you know?

question: That cheap aftershave I send you every Christmas, you actually wear it. I'm touched. Sit down, sit down, what brings you to Mombassa?
answer: You. Tell me, Roland, when was the last time you answered your phone?

question: Last time I plugged it in, I suppose. Why?
answer: I got a call from a gentleman who's going to Costa Rica, or thereabouts. If he's to be believed, it's a most, uh, unique expedition. And very well-funded.

question: Well, I'm a very well-funded old son of a bitch. You go.
answer: But alone? We always had great success together, you and I.

question: Just a little bit too much, I think.
answer: How do you mean?

question: A true hunter doesn't mind if the animal wins. If it escapes. But there weren't enough escapes from you and me, Ajay. I've decided to spend a bit less time in the company of death. Maybe I just feel too close to it my-- I can think of none greater. What do I have to do to pick a fight with you, bring your mother into it? Really? Sorry. We were saying?
answer: You broke that idiot's jaw for no reason other than your boredom. Tell the truth, Roland. Aren't you even interested in knowing this expedition's quarry?

question: We leave in twenty-four hours. Five member team. Eddie Carr's handling all our equipment and he'll be there to maintain it. He's designing special field trailers now, top of the line mobile research units.
answer: No, no, look at the plans, Henry, you can't place that strut laterally, it has to be crosswise, LOOK AT THE PLANS!

question: Any damage?
answer: Minimal.

question: "Minimal" is too much. It has to be light, it has to be strong --
answer: Light and strong, light and strong, sure, why not, it's only impossible. God save me from academics.

question: You are an academic.
answer: Former academic. Now I actually make things. I don't just talk.

question: You think I'm all talk, Eddie?
answer: It doesn't matter what I think.

question: Is there anything we've forgotten? Anything at all?
answer: Hi, Dad.

question: Kelly! What are you doing here?
answer: Vacation. I'm all yours. You didn't forget, did you?

question: Okay, Karen is expecting you in half an hour. You only have to stay with her one night, she'll put you on a bus in the morning and your mother will be at the station when you get there.
answer: I don't even know this woman.

question: Well, I do, and she's fantastic. She'll take you to the museum, maybe to a movie if you play your cards right. You're going to have a fantastic time.
answer: Stop saying fantastic. Where are you going?

question: I can't tell you. But I'll be back within a week.
answer: My vacation is over in a week.

question: I'll make it up to you this summer. I promise.
answer: I'm your daughter all the time, you know. Not just when it's convenient.

question: Very hurtful. Your mother tell you to say that?
answer: No, Dad. I have thoughts of my own once in a while.

question: Is that kid still bothering you?
answer: Which one?

question: You know, at the bus stop. With the hair?
answer: That was about a year ago.

question: Well, is he?
answer: No. Richard talked to his parents.

question: That Richard.
answer: I could come with you.

question: Out of the question. You'd miss the gymnastics trials. You've been training for that for a year.
answer: I don't care about the trials, I want to be with you. I could be your research assistant, like I was in Austin.

question: This is nothing like Austin. Forget about it.
answer: You like to have kids, you just don't want to be with them, do you?

question: So what's your story, Nick?
answer: I was a cameraman for Nightline for six years, been freelance since '91. Do a lot of work for Greenpeace.

question: That must be interesting. What drew you there?
answer: Women. 'Bout eighty percent female in Greenpeace.

question: Very noble of you. You don't think you're bringing that thing onto the island, do you?
answer: Hey, I wouldn't want to spook the woolly mammoths.

question: You think this is all a joke?
answer: Oh, please. How am I supposed to keep a straight face when -- -- Johnny Cash here tells me I'm going to Skull Island?

question: Ian's a very good friend of mine.
answer: He doesn't need a friend, he needs a shrink.

question: I believe in him.
answer: Come on, there's only one reason any of us are here. His check cleared.

question: It's beautiful!
answer: Stegosaurus, family Stegosauridae, infraorder Stegosauria, suborder Thyreophora. Length, adult male, estimate twenty-five to thirty feet.

question: That was a pair bond! A family group, even, long after that infant was nestbound!
answer: I want to see the nesting ground!

question: Lone nest -- not colonial. I don't see an egg clutch...
answer: The empty shells are crushed and trampled. The young stay in the birth environment, that's conclusive!

question: And let's forget about the high hide. We can't do this kind of work up in a tower, we need to be out in the field, as close to the animals as possible.
answer: I'm not surprised stegosaur lived in a family group, but there's never been anything in the fossil record to prove the carnivores did.

question: Why wouldn't they? Look at hyenas, jackals, nearly all species of predator birds --
answer: That doesn't say a thing about T-rex, they could have been rogues. Robert Burke certainly thinks they were.

question: Welcome to your dream come true, Dr. Burke.
answer: I believe the large herbivores forage in open plains, like bison, which would explain the great variety of heat dots we're reading in the flatlands around this waterhole. Right -- here.

question: Then that's where we're going.
answer: Hadrosaurus! Carinthosaurus! Maiasaurus!

question: This is as good a place as any for base camp. First priority is the laser barriers, I want them all up and running in thirty minutes. Half an hour, understand?
answer: Cancel that, Dieter.

question: What? Why?
answer: Carnivores hunt near stream beds. Do you want to set up base camp or an all-you-can-eat people bar?

question: You heard his, Dieter. Find a new spot. And remember, we're after herbivores only -- no unnecessary risks.
answer: Peter, if you want me to run your little camping trip, there are two conditions. First -- I'm in charge, and when I'm not around, Dieter is. Your job is to sign the checks, tell us we're doing a good job, and open your case of scotch when we have a good day. Second condition -- my fee. You can keep it. All I want in exchange for my services is the right to hunt one of the tyrannosaurs. A male. Buck only. Why and how are my business. If you don't like either of those conditions, you're on your own. Go ahead and set up your camp right here, or in a swamp, or in the middle of a rex nest, for all I care. But I've been on too many safaris with rich dentists to listen to any more suicidal ideas. Okay?

question: Okay.
answer: Good lad.

question: Offering a little incentive.
answer: What kind of gun is that?

question: My father's .600 Nitro Express. Made in 1904. Karimojo Bell gave it to him after he took down his last elephant. 8700 foot pound striking force.
answer: How close do you have to be?

question: Forty yards. Less, maybe. I assume it'll take a slug in the brain case to bring him down.
answer: Why not just use a scope and a poison dart and snipe him from a hill?

question: Or a laser beam from a satellite?
answer: You rally think this'll draw the parent?

question: I once saw a bull elephant die charging a jeep. All the jeep had done was startle the bull's calves. I saw a lioness carry wounded prey four and a half miles, all the way back to its den, just to teach its cubs how to finish off a kill.
answer: Killing lessons? Heartwarming.

question: Rex won't be any different. It'll come.
answer: You're kidding yourself. An adult T-rex cares about one thing -- filling its own belly. It acts the way people wish they could, that's why everyone's fascinated by it. If people had the chance to see one dinosaur and one only, ninety-nine percent would --

question: What?
answer: I hadn't planned on bringing carnivores back because of the liability risk, but I only thought of adults, it never occurred to me -- You are a billion dollar idea, my little f-

question: What the hell you do that for?!
answer: Had to. To keep him still for the trip.

question: You've broken its leg!
answer: We've got to transport it seven thousand miles. Would you prefer it bit off the leg of a crew member?

question: looks to her right, at a metal grating that runs along the wall of the trailer. She shifts her weight, leaning on one hand to reach for the grating with the other.
answer: reaches for the satellite phone, its antenna just six inches from his outstretched fingers.

question: leans toward the metal grating, all hairline cracks shoot out around her pivot hand, shaking through the glass. The splintered glass spread like a disease, it reaches the edge of the frame --
answer: has two fingers on the phone, but suddenly the whole trailer shudders and the heavy phone tips off the table leg and falls. SARAH LOOK OUT!

question: There's a communication center, here, in the old worker village. Hammond put in some kind of renewable power source replenishing. It may still work. If we could get there, we could send a radio call for the airlift.
answer: How far is the village?

question: I said if we could get there.
answer: Well, how far is it?

question: No. I'm quite certain you can't.
answer: Look, we have two choices. We can hike back down to the lagoon, where we can sit for two days, in the open, next to a heavily used water source while we're waiting for your boat to arrive, or we can head for the village, where we might find some shelter and we can call for help.

question: We'd never make it past the raptors. Trust me, I have some experience in this matter.
answer: That may be. But you weren't with me at the time.

question: Damn it.
answer: You all right?

question: You ever heard of Gambler's Ruin?
answer: What's that?

question: A statistical phenomenon. Says everything in the world goes in streaks. It's real, you see it everywhere -- in weather, in river flooding, in baseball, in blackjack, in stock markets. Once things go bad, they tend to stay bad. Bad things cluster. They go to hell together.
answer: Feeling a bit blue, are we?

question: Just -- flawed. Very deeply flawed.
answer: Why did you come here?

question: So that others would know about this place?
answer: Why should they?

question: Because it exists.
answer: It'll still exit if they go on not knowing, won't it?

question: Yes. And people will live in the absence of truth.
answer: So the truth is more important to you than your life?

question: I don't care about my life. But if I'd ever thought for a second that she would be in danger --
answer: She yours? Somewhere on this island, there exits the greatest predator that ever lived. And the second greatest predator must take him down.

question: But why?
answer: You remember that guy, about twenty years ago, I forget his name, but he climbed Everest without any oxygen, came down almost dead. And they asked him, "why did you go up there to die?" And he said "I didn't. I went up there to live."

question: It's called self-testing. But in your case, it sounds more like self-destruction. A uniquely human characteristic. In fact, human beings destroy things so well that I sometimes think that's our function. Maybe every few sons, some animal comes along that kills off the rest of the world, clears the decks, and lets evolution proceed to his next phase. Maybe death and destruction are our job, maybe we're supposed to destroy ourselves and every other living thing that-
answer: Tell you what. You can see whatever you want to, to me, but you will not spew any more nihilist rants at anyone else in the group. I'm fighting panic, and you push the wrong buttons. Understand?

question: You go if you like, but we're not waiting for you. MOVE IT OUT!!
answer: You okay?

question: Looks like the worker village is down in there, about a mile and a half northeast from the base of these cliffs.
answer: There must be a game trail, some kind of path that goes down there.

question: We're downwind. Good.
answer: We took to the rock.

question: Why?
answer: Wind shift.

question: It's... behind... us.
answer: It's just fed. It won't attack unless it's threatened. Don't move.

question: If I don't move, I can't shoot it.
answer: Let it go, Peter. The animal won.

question: There it is!
answer: Ian. It's guano.

question: What?
answer: These formations. They're dried --

question: Birdshit?
answer: Who cares? Let's go!

question: Kelly?! KELLY?!
answer: Come on!

question: Where's Kelly?
answer: She's with Sarah!

question: We can't stay in here!
answer: We're sure as hell not going back out there"

question: This is single-wall construction! It's just a shack!
answer: It'll hold!

question: For sixty seconds, maybe! Look at this! You could-
answer: Head for the roof!

question: I have to find Kelly!
answer: I think she's with Sarah!

question: It's too wide!
answer: Help me push this! It's afraid to come onto the roof!

question: Something's wrong.
answer: Look! Sarah!
